p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the sixth report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and Ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 25 January 2023, 8 February 2023 and 15 February 2023.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 58 petitio
ns in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 7 petitioners—requesting a ban on baby walkers with seats (EN4651)
From 27 petitioners—requesting funding for Alambi aged care facility in Dimboola (EN4652)
From 1109 petitioners—requesting changes to make it easier for cancer patients to access social welfare (EN4653)
From 9 petitioners—requesting that Iran's Islamic Republic regime be listed as a terrorist organisation (EN4655)
From 2020 petitioners—requesting the recognition of pharmacists as valid healthcare providers and prescribers (EN4656)
From 15 petitioners—requesting a review of the ATO in relation to tax on small business (EN4657)
From 10 petitioners—requesting abolition of compulsory voting (EN4658)
From 11 petitioners—requesting amendment to assessment of veteran's pension (EN4659)
From 8 petitioners—requesting asylum for Chinese students currently in Australia (EN4660)
From 6 petitioners—requesting an amendment to the Medicare levy surcharge for domestic violence victims (EN4663)
From 16 petitioners—requesting a ban on all non-biodegradable soft plastics (EN4664)
From 7 petitioners—requesting a change to quarterly reports for self-managed superannuation funds (EN4665)
From 5 petitioners—requesting a new law for data retention, protection and privacy (EN4667)
From 29356 petitioners—requesting an inquiry into Australia's Covid-19 response (EN4670)
From 79 petitioners—requesting regulation of public official's statements about climate change (EN4671)
From 48 petitioners—requesting a law to prevent social media restriction promotion of parliamentary petitions (EN4674)
From 1077 petitioners—requesting action to prevent the Chalumbin Wind Farm environmental approval (EN4675)
From 14 petitioners—requesting an alternative pathway to general registration for international medical graduates (EN4677)
From 23 petitioners—requesting the elimination of daylight savings time (EN4678)
From 7 petitioners—requesting regulation of childcare centres to waive fees on sick days (EN4680)
From 25 petitioners—requesting recognition for the state of Palestine (EN4681)
From 12 petitioners—requesting Australian action against Iran (EN4682)
From 60 petitioners—requesting that family sponsored refugee visas be fast tracked (EN4685)
From 22 petitioners—requesting the use of surplus cruise ships as housing (EN4686)
From 89 petitioners—requesting changes to the parliamentary petitions process (EN4687)
From 4 petitioners—requesting funding for PCR testing (EN4688)
From 5 petitioners—requesting legislation to mandate personal methane sequestering (EN4689)
From 450 petitioners—requesting an extension to Homebuilder grant documentation for off-the-plan applicants (EN4691)
From 3 petitioners—requesting changes to income tax rules for fundraisers (EN4696)
From 20 petitioners—requesting legislation to make cancelling digital subscriptions easier (EN4697)
From 1264 petitioners—requesting Automated External Defibrillators be mandatory for businesses with public access (EN4699)
From 44 petitioners—requesting changes to allow point-based-skilled-visa-applicants to have a spouse or de-facto partner (EN4700)
From 11 petitioners—requesting disaster relief grants for flood stricken Cabonne residents (EN4701)
From 73 petitioners—requesting the regulation of drug and alcohol rehabilitation and treatment centres (EN4704)
From 197 petitioners—requesting funding for court-ordered psychiatric assessments (EN4705)
From 19 petitioners—requesting changes to conditions of visa classes 491 and 494 (EN4709)
From 6 petitioners—requesting consideration of whether to support China to join the CPTPP (EN4711)
From 5 petitioners—requesting changes to medicinal marijuana use in Australia (EN4713)
From 15 petitioners—requesting a change to policy to allow people with ADHD and autism to join the ADF (EN4715)
From 4 petitioners—requesting changes to sick leave (EN4716)
From 627 petitioners—requesting minimum minutes for healthcare in nursing homes (EN4717)
From 1 petitioners—requesting permanent residency for some students (EN4718)
From 11 petitioners—requesting that the government bring the remaining Bali nine back to Australia (EN4721)
From 6 petitioners—requesting mandatory COVID test for people coming from China (EN4722)
From 9 petitioners—requesting changes to control of schedule 8 medications (EN4725)
From 4 petitioners—requesting restrictions on travel from China due to recent covid outbreak (EN4726)
From 4 petitioners—requesting Covid testing at the border (EN4728)
From 119 petitioners—requesting increases to the Medicare rebate (EN4729)
From 4 petitioners—requesting health checks upon arrival on travellers from China (EN4731)
From 5 petitioners—requesting the removal of testing mandates on travellers from China (EN4732)
From 127 petitioners—requesting criminalization of sexual acts with minors (EN4736)
From 390 petitioners—requesting funding for the Trove website (EN4737)

span.span: 2. The following 10 ministerial responses to petitions were received by the Committee on 15 February 2023:

p.span: From the Minister for Communications to a petition regarding increasing numbers of online scams (EN3472)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding a review of the provision of foreign aid (EN3549)
From the Minister for Regional Development, Local Government and Territories to a petition requesting the return the NT to Federal control (EN3572)
From the Minister for Veterans Affairs to a petition regarding amending the Veterans Acts (EN4196)
From the Minister for Veterans Affairs to a petition requesting a review of defining "evidence" under the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 (VEA) (EN4205)
From the Minister for Veterans Affairs to a petition requesting a change to Veterans Entitlement 1986 Act (VEA) and procedural apprehended bias (EN4353)
From the Minister for Veterans Affairs to a petition requesting a law amendment to the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986" (EN4381)
From the Minister for Veterans Affairs to a petition regarding the confirmation of the RMA definition of "clinical onset" (EN4382)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting to stop general practitioners (GP) charging fees above Medicare rebates (EN4485)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting to block international scam calls (EN4518)
In Report 06 presented on 13 February 2023 the incorrect petition number (EN3528) was given to a response from the Minister for the Public Service. The correct information is:
From the Minister for the Public Service to a petition regarding a mandate for all public servants to be vaccinated (EN3548)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 58 petitions:
Child Safety
Baby walkers with wheels pose a risk to a child's safety and development.

Researchers suggest baby walkers place a child in an atypical standing position, inadvertently promoting external rotation and pointed toes and this can put unnecessary force on joints, creating an abnormal walking pattern and impacting typical muscle development.
The child can be hurt when using the device either by falling down stairs when too close, going too fast and hiting objects and potentially being able to grab hazardous objects.
Baby walkers with seats have been outlawed in Canada, why can't we here in Australia.?
We therefore ask the House to legislate and ban the sale of baby walkers with seats.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN4651)
Aged Care

Alambi Aged Care Facility is an asset in our local town which provides a much valued resource for our local aged community. Located in a familiar environment for residents, it also enables families easy access to visit. The facility also offers employment for local residents.

We therefore ask the House to look at a more flexible model of the Aged Care Standards for our smaller rural Aged Care Facilities. There are real issues with availability of nursing staff in rural areas, and if there was some flexibility with regard to the current standards, our facility would have a better chance of continuing its service.
Rural towns usually only have smaller facilities that the larger Providers are reluctant to take over.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN4652)
Pensions and Benefits
Legislation, as it currently is drafted, is severely limiting in what cancer patients can access in terms of pension/social welfare payments.
As it's currently drafted, a disability pension is only available for cancer patients where a person's condition is considered terminal—and they have two years to live or less.
One major problem is that to be eligible for the disability support pension, a person's condition must be "fully diagnosed, fully treated and fully stabilised".

This means that a cancer patient could be treated for years, decades even, without ever having access to a disability pension. Yes the Jobseeker payment is available, but you are still required to either a. attend job interviews/make applications or b. receive a note from your doctor that you are unwell.

Things need to change. Legislation needs to either be amended to include cancer patients into the definition of a disability or it needs to be introduced to include a cancer pension for the duration of a person's treatment. The current system is not fair.
We therefore ask the House to review the current legislation surrounding support pensions, and provide greater support to cancer patients during their treatment.
from 1,109 citizens (Petition No. EN4653)
Human Rights: Iran

The Islamic Republic regime (IR) in Iran has been systematically murdering peaceful secular, anti-regime protesters, including women and schoolchildren. These actions by the Ayatollah's fundamentalist Islamic megacultists constitute dire human rights abuses. Reliable reports from multiple sources put the death toll at over 340 people to date.

The Islamic megacultists that are responsible are a worldwide movement that has supporters and representatives in Australia. IR's ideology, links to other terrorist groups, and links to Australia make them a terror risk.

There have been incidents of IR supporters intimidating and assaulting women protesters of the regime in the UK. This is completely unacceptable behaviour, as is the behaviour of the Islamic moral police in Iran.

Measures should be taken to ensure that IR and its megacult leader—Ayatollah Ali Khamenei—are not seen to be supported by our nation in any sense. Furthermore, unambiguous measures should be taken ensure that Islamic Republic supporters are prevented from ever assailing, intimidating, or accosting Iranian or non-Iranian secularists in this country.

We therefore ask the House to direct the Minister for Home affairs and legislative assembly to add the Islamic Republic regime of Iran to Australia's list of terrorist organisations (Division 102 of the Commonwealth Criminal Code Act 1995), deport all IR followers from Australia, and seize all assets of IR (The Charter of the United Nations Act 1945). Simultaneously, we ask that Iranian democratic-secularist protesters—especially women, children, and young people—be provided with special emergency Visas and asylum in Australia.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4655)
Health Care: Pharmacists

Pharmacists are not listed on the Application for a Medicare provider number and, or prescriber number for allied health and non-medical health professionals form (HW093). According to The Health Professionals Prescribing Pathway (HPPP) prescribing means "an iterative process involving the steps of information gathering, clinical decision making, communication and evaluation which results in the initiation, continuation or cessation of a medicine."

According to Pharmacy Board: "The pharmacist must be satisfied that there is a therapeutic need". Pharmacist undertakes a process that reflects the components of the prescribing process to establish therapeutic need, i.e., communication, clinical information gathering, clinical decision making based on their assessment, other medical conditions, other medicines, ruling out interactions or other physiological conditions of the patient, history, determining the most appropriate drug therapy.

Pharmacists fit into the HPPP defined principles seeing that: Pharmacists ensure that the health, wellbeing, and safety of the person taking a medicine is always maintained. Pharmacists prescribe within their individual and professional scope of practice S2, S3 and S4 vaccines and are accountable for their actions.

When pharmacists treat their patients with same medicines then they are not considered clinicians and remunerated in similar way as other medical or non-medical health professionals. Pharmacists need provider numbers to access MBS for their professional advice, diagnosis, assessment, and management of minor ailments.

We therefore ask the House to recognise pharmacists as valid healthcare providers and prescribers for S2, S3 and future S4 medicines and make changes to the form HW093 to include AHPRA registered pharmacists.
from 2,020 citizens (Petition No. EN4656)
Australian Taxation Office

The ATO have hit small business with GST debts that don't exist without asking for receipts or evidence. The lack of communication has cost Australian small business copious amounts of money in a time of need & compassion, not tightening the grip of hard working Australian's.
The complaints to ATO are at an all time high with up 4 weeks wait time for a reply, an all time high! Which shows how Australia is unhappy with what we have been dealt.

We therefore ask the House to audit the ATO for 'robodebt' schemes, hitting hard working Australians where it hurts & crushing their dreams, motivation & need to feed their families with an all time high inflation.
Eradicate these false debts.
Pay tax returns in a timely manner.
Better communication with tax payers/small business.
Hiring more people to stay on top of tasks and better communication.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN4657)
Conduct of Elections
Abolish compulsory vote because the elections are not being run properly and numbers are fudged

We therefore ask the House to examine elections then abolish compulsory vote. The count numbers are never right .as a candidate in a election I know something is not right. I ran in a couple elections long story short when I questioned a certain booth numbers I was told no one voted for me I said well that's impossible as I voted as my family voted so I know I got numbers then by some miracle all of a sudden I got numbers. This is a federal issue as it happens in every election in every state something needs to be done if this epetition is brushed aside it proves government does not care about people and their rights to a honest and fair election system .
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4658)
Veterans

I'm a veteran currently receiving a services pension from DVA they have assessed DFRDB as Defined Benefit income stream. They applied asset test which has reduced my service pension. The changes in legislation registered 20 Oct 2022 allows for asset-test exemption for defined benefit income stream. DFRDB is a defined benefit income stream DVA uses the term to describe DFRDB.

We therefore ask the House to determine that DFRDB is an income stream that is asset-test exempt income stream for the purposes of the Act. The DFRDB income stream is a defined benefit income stream and has been so from the day the income stream began being paid. I'm requesting DFRDB be recognised as exempt from asset-testing.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN4659)
Human Rights: China

On the evening of 23 November, 10 lives were lost in an Urumqi apartment fire to draconian COVID measures, as fire services struggled to penetrate COVID roadblocks. Authorities denied locking the fire corridor, and blamed the tragedy on "some people's weak self-rescue abilities".

Demonstrations in Urumqi on 25 November occurred from dusk until dawn. As the whole of China awoke to witness the courage of Urumqi residents, extraordinary solidarity ensued. From Kashgar in the West to Shanghai in the East, in universities, metro stations and city streets, the rallying cries and the silent blank-paper protests have been loud and clear.

In China, one positive COVID case triggers the lockdown of whole city blocks, with residents prohibited from exiting their front door. This obsolete zero-COVID policy continues for one reason alone—Xi Jinping is a megalomaniac who would rather continue making greater mistakes to avoid admitting previous ones.

The Urumqi tragedy is not the most devastating, but the Chinese people is venting their pent-up fury. Instead of abolishing zero-COVID, authorities made incomplete compromises and cracked down on protests. We must continue to speak for the indivisibility of human rights—whether it's China, Iran, Russia, Syria or Palestine.

We therefore ask the House to offer political asylum to Chinese students currently in Australia, as the Hawke Government did after the 1989 crackdown, and to allocate more resources to asylum processing. We also ask the House to condemn intimidation against all Australian-based activists.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN4660)
Private Health Insurance

The Medicare levy surcharge (MLS) compel spouses to ensure their partners or dependent children (under 21 or 24 if studying) are fully privately insured otherwise, regardless of their own full private medical insurance, they too will be penalised as "uninsured" and forced to pay the levy (in addition to the private insurance premiums).
From the ATO website
"A Medicare levy surcharge may apply if you, your spouse and all your dependants did not maintain an appropriate level of private patient hospital cover for the full income year."

The situation is that a fully privately insured person will pay the MLS due to the decision of another person. Domestic violence victims and people in coercive relationships may be unable to compel their spouse or children to be fully insured and yet the ATO will penalise this person. This is not only unacceptable for victims of domestic violence but for any individual person. A person should not have a financial penalty imposed upon them for the for the decision of another adult person, particularly when they are paying private insurance costs. This is an unfair penalty.

We therefore ask the House to amend the Medicare levy surcharge (MLS) to remove the penalty for a fully privately insured person who has an uninsured spouse or child over eighteen years. The privately insured party must not be penalised by the MLS for the full or partial taxation year, if their spouse or child chooses not to have private health insurance during the same period.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4663)
Waste Management and Recycling

Due to the growing evidence of climate change and the increasing need to reduce our impact on the environment we need to remove all non biodegradable soft plastics from our packaging. Alternatives are available but we have been reliant on the soft packaging recycling scheme run by redcycle. As this has now been indefinitely stopped it is imperative we make industry only use biodegradable soft plastics on our products to reduce waste in landfill and reduce our impact on the environment.

We therefore ask the House to enforce the removal of all non biodegradable soft plastics in all forms of packaging and ensure suitable punishments are in place and enforced for all industry that refuses to comply with the change within a reasonable time frame
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN4664)
Superannuation
According to https://www.ato.gov.au/Super/Sup/Changes-to-annual-lodgments-of-TBAR/
older Australians who hold their savings in an SMSF would soon be forced to send a TBAR report every quarter, even if their SMSF had no TBAR transactions.

TBAR events are relatively rare and many SMSFs can go for years without any. Ordinary people, how more so older people, cannot fill a TBAR report themselves, so they would have to contact their accountants for this service every quarter without fail, pay for their service and most troubling, will have to constantly be aware of and concerned about the tax-quarters, for if they forget about them (or happen to be too ill at the time to bother about them) they could face penalties and other hardships.
We therefore ask the House to at least not require the lodging of empty TBAR quarterly reports when an SMSF had no TBAR events for the quarter.

Further, there is no need to require frequent TBAR reporting at all when the events reported, such as the drawing of a lump-sum from a pension stream, could, if anything, only potentially benefit the SMSF owner, that too only in rare cases.
Also, it should be made easier for SMSFs to report TBAR events themselves online as they occur, rather than collate them up quarterly or annually and require a professional to lodge them.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN4665)
Cybersecurity

The recent major cybersecurity attacks and breaches on various major Australian organisations such as Optus, Medibank, Centerlink and ATO shows how broken the current Australian data retention, protection and privacy laws is right now. This is not helping at all in terms of protecting vulnerable Australians from scammers along with protecting our sensitive personal information. Therefore we urge the Australian Government to draft, ratify and implement a EU GDPR styled data retention, protection and privacy law reform now not later.
We therefore ask the House to prioritise and urgently draft, ratify and implement a EU GDPR styled data retention, protection and privacy law reform now not later.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4667)
COVID-19: Response
The significant impact on all Australians by the Covid-19 pandemic response, which has now been independently reviewed demonstrating the need for full inquiries.
We express our overwhelming concern for the following:

*From 2020 until present day, State and Federal Governments as well as many private companies have habitually breached inviolable, absolute non-derogable human rights and Australia's international obligations.
*The lack of transparency in all Public Health decisions particularly the disproportionate and non-evidence-based directions and mandates.
*The financial cost to the people and as a nation.
*Impact on children's education and mental health.
*Provisionally approved treatments and injections with no long-term safety data.
*The suppression and lack of early treatment to save the vulnerable.
*The number of Covid-19 vaccine adverse event reports and lack in the evaluation of the potential correlation.
*The excess mortality in 2022.
*The interference with the doctor patient relationship and the suspension of professionals, without reasonable or fair process.
*The censorship by opinion not fact, of all who shared information that differed from the government narrative.
*The incitement and actions of public servants that resulted in the immoral and degrading treatment of Australians.
*The advertising and promotion of Covid-19 vaccines by government departments and politicians that do not align with the statutory regulations.

We therefore ask the House to invoke the Hon Governor-General to establish a Commonwealth Royal Commission into the Covid-19 Pandemic response in Australia by issuing a Letters Patent under the Royal Commissions Act 1902 (Cth) and initiate an AHRC inquiry into the violation of human rights, on a federal, territory and state basis.
from 29,356 citizens (Petition No. EN4670)
Climate Change

Climate change narrative is the biggest money spinner for the global elite, many of the actors in the Climate Change debate have financial interests and many are using public officials as a system of repeating false and misleading statements. To date, not a single prediction by any of the so-called Climate Change experts has been proven correct. Many have altered and skewed the facts to suit their narrative, which can lead to systemic corruption.

It should be an offence to knowingly make a false statement to mislead, or attempt to mislead the taxpayers of Australia who bare the ultimate financial burden of the claims that cannot be backed up with historical and real evidence.

The use of words like; May, Could and Might, are not facts. Modeling purporting to be future events are not facts. Placing the burden on Australian Taxpayers based on false and misleading statements should not be protected by any parliamentary privilege and be regarded as an integrity offence.
We therefore ask the House to

1/ Regulate the false and misleading claims regarding Climate Change made by Public officials and make it an integrity offence to make false and misleading Climate Change statements as this goes against the Public Interest.
2/ Include this as an offence within the Public Interest Disclosure Act 2012
from 79 citizens (Petition No. EN4671)
Parliamentary Petitions: Digital Platforms

Social media has been active in censoring, deleting, demoting, and restricting verified Parliamentary e-petitions. An e-petition is a request for action. The right to petition Federal Parliament has been one of the rights of citizens since federation, and it is the only way an individual can directly place grievances before the Parliament. The presentation of a petition to the Senate is a proceeding in Parliament and is protected by parliamentary privilege.
Social media companies that censor an e-petition or place restrictions on e-petitions are in fact interfering with a parliamentary process and interfering in the affairs of Australia's society.
The majority of Social media companies are foreign-owned and this amounts to foreign interference in the functions of the Australian Government.
We therefore ask the House to
Make it contempt of parliament for any Media or Social Media company to restrict, delete, demote, hide or unpublish any fair and factual promotion of any Australian Parliamentary e-petition.
from 48 citizens (Petition No. EN4674)
Renewable Energy

The developer has failed to engage in open community consultation forums. The developer has actively avoided holding or attending open community meetings, instead engaging in one on one and small group 'information sessions'.
In addition the developer has misled the community about the development.
In the draft Public Environment Report Ark Energy provides contradictory, false and misleading information. The document fails to
meet the Guidelines for the Content of a draft PER Chalumbin Wind Farm.
We therefore ask the House to reject the development in it's entirety
from 1,077 citizens (Petition No. EN4675)
General Practitioners: Registration

Traditionally, International Medical Graduates (IMGs) need to complete the AMC MCQ exam, AMC clinical exam and 12 months of supervised hospital work to meet the board requirements for general registration. For IMGs who choose to work in General Practice in Australia, an additional exam, the Pre-Employment Structured Clinical Interview (PESCI), is required. It is important to note that IMGs who choose to work in hospitals are not required to complete the PESCI which is is clinical interview administered by certified medical educators of specialist colleges such as the RACGP and ACRRM.

The Health Department justifies the need for the PESCI based on the belief that IMGs in general practice require additional clinical screening and skills at a level more advanced than their peers in the hospitals due to lack of comparable suprevision arrangements for junior doctors in general practice settings. Unfortunately, IMGs who have completed the PESCI, in addition to years of clinical work in general practice are only eligible for limited registration and are still required to complete the AMC clinical examinations in order to meet the medical board requirements for general registration.

An IMG that has shown proficiency in a general practice setting where comprehensive structural supervision is believed to be lacking, compared to the hospital, should ideally be considered proficient and eligible for general registration.
We therefore ask the House to consider the completion of the PESCI and a specified period of supervision should therefore be an acceptable pathway to general registration.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4677)
Daylight Saving

Daylight savings has been shown in many studies to be detrimental to the health and wellbeing of people, without the purported benefits claimed when it was introduced. Major world powers such as the European Union and USA are already in the process of eliminating daylight savings time changes. Australia is lagging behind the world by clinging on to daylight savings long after it has been proven worse than ineffective.

We therefore ask the House to pass a federal law eliminating daylight savings from all states and territories. This can certainly be done at a federal level to overrule the state and territory legislations, as is currently underway in both EU and USA.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN4678)
Child Care

This is well known to every parent in Australia that childcares are charging families even on sick days when kids are not even attending them. So technically it's putting a dent on the government CCS program as well as family's budgets, sadly.
What I don't understand is why are they allowed to charge us even though their staff does not even have to look after our kids and their resources are not consumed at all.

We therefore ask the House to provide an audience for this serious matter. This is not just for me and my kids, it is for every parent in Australia so this is a pressing issue worthy of your attention.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN4680)
Middle East

Palestine is under an active occupation right now! Israel continues to violate basic human rights and build illegal settlements, none of which are recognised by Australia and allies such as the USA. If the illegal occupation is not stopped right now, Australia's official position of a two-state solution will never become a reality and the Palestinian people will continue to live under the occupation. The occupation must stop now! Australia must play its part to advocate, preserve and protect human rights that are a core part of the Australian society! Australia must be on the right side of history!

We therefore ask the House to officially recognise a Palestinian state with secure and recognised borders. At a time when UN and the world's leading human rights organisations are openly labelling Israel's policies against Palestinians as the crime of apartheid, our government must take greater action in supporting the Palestinian people in their demand for justice and freedom!
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN4681)
Human Rights: Iran

Iranian authorities have executed a protester, sentenced to death in show trials without any due process.His charges: Moharebeh" for closing the street and injuring an officer. His name is #MohsenShekari—He was hanged early this morning. #IranRevolution2022
Mohammad Mehdi Karami is a prisoner who was tortured to confess to a murder he didn't commit. Be his voice.
Sahand Noormohammadzadeh, a bodybuilding champion, was arrested and then charged with Moharebeh for trying to tear down the street guardrail. His life is in serious danger. Be his voice.
#saytheirnames
Mohsen Shekari was accused of blocking a street and also attacking a security force as an act of self defense. They executed him today. This execution must have rapid consequences internationally.
We therefore ask the House to put pressures on IRAN to stop executing of protesters
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN4682)
Refugee and Humanitarian Program

This is a humble plea from a 64-year-old mother to request family sponsored offshore refugee visa for Myanmar citizens to process as an urgent priority. My two sons' families are currently fleeing from their home country due to a threat to their lives and fear of prosecution by the military government in Myanmar due to their involvement in civil disobedience. The reason for the request is they are currently residing in Thailand and the Philippines, struggling to retain valid visas every month with the increasing cost of living and visa extension expenses in seeking refuge in foreign countries currently. Thailand's government is now becoming difficult for Myanmar citizens to gain legal stay. They are on the brink of running out of money to continue staying in a safe location out of Myanmar legally as well as their mental health is rapidly declining. As a mother, I am in constant worry for their safety and mental health as there have been mentions of psychological distress due to the possibility of deportation. As a desperate mother, I am trying to migrate them to Australia urgently. I eagerly request your empathetic support in our uncertain journey to a safe country of refuge by signing this petition.

We therefore ask the House to consider prioritising my two sons family sponsored offshore refugee visa and look into their cases so that I can be reunited with my sons. I collected over 100 signatures on paper in support of petition within my community available at request.
from 60 citizens (Petition No. EN4685)
Housing

After COVID, the cruise industry across the world is discarding billions of dollars' worth of cruise ships. A brand-new ship with 9000 passenger cabins is about to be towed directly from the shipyard to the scrapyard.
This egregious failure of capitalism can be redeemed.
A cruise ship is a self-contained town with (generally) high-quality accommodation, entertainment, shops, sickbays, etc. A ship also provides appropriate power generation, waste treatment, etc.
Cruise ships can be tied up at all major cities and used to quickly bring housing capacity 'online.'

Brisbane's Portside dock is also about to be decommissioned due to purely commercial reasons. This facility appears ready-made to support a long-term ship tie-up. There are probably similar unused/under-used facilities in many Australian major cities.
There is currently no other proposition that offers such a quick response to the housing crisis as this. Even if only used as a temporary solution, this would be better than nothing.
There is precedent: cruise ships have elsewhere been repurposed as floating hotels, hospitals and even university campuses.
We therefore ask the House to apply this potential solution to a major social problem as expeditiously as possible.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN4686)
Parliamentary Petitions
Currently these petitions put no obligation on any office or minster to do anything, in response, or anything at all as a result.
There is not obligation to:
provide feedback
Provide progress updates
Even a response to the community of petition supporters.
Should it not be too much to expect that:
a) This process places obligation and measurement reporting on what has happened to the petition in process and outcomes delivered as part of what change the petition was addressing.

b) That each petition should obligate a response / multiple responses from government. Requiring updates (measured by reporting obligations of time) to provide updates to each petition. With time frames measured to ensure compliance by said ministers office to respond.
c) That all petitions are bought together into a spreadsheet, made available to the Australian communities, as a reporting on the effectiveness of these petitions. That would reveal:
i) How many petitions have been created
ii) To which minister / department have they been sent.
iii) What changes have been implemented by the ministers office as a result of the petitions levied and signed by the Australian population.
iv) Consultation with the Australian Population as to what other reporting metrics they would like to have made visible.
d) that public measurement and accountability should be intrinsic to this process.
We therefore ask the House to revamp the entire petition process to introduce measurement, accountability, effectiveness and reporting metrics to the entire process of these Petitions.
from 89 citizens (Petition No. EN4687)
COVID-19: Testing

The federal government has removed funding for PCR testing, requiring citizens to obtain a referral from a GP or nurse. This removal of funding has occurred less than one month before the start of a new wave, with an increasing infection rate and increasing death rate. At the date of announcement of this change, there were nearly as many active cases as during the previous wave and more than one third the highest recorded level Australia has seen. The death rate was already up to one third that of the previous wave and close to one third the highest 7-day moving average Australia has seen.

We therefore ask the House to re-instate the funding for PCR testing at will. This is absolutely necessary for the health of Australian citizens, as the new rules will increase the infection rates even higher than they would if testing were still available to all citizens.
Additionally, the house should consider providing RATs for free to all Australian citizens, as should have been considered during 2021 when they first became available.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4688)
Climate Change
Australia's population approaches 30 million people. We all create methane gas escaping to the atmosphere, some more than others.
We are seeing the consequences with floods, bushfires and unpredictable weather.
Doing nothing is no longer an option. Australia is a great country of innovation, for example the cochlear implant.

The Federal Government must mandate the capture of human methane and direct resources to the provision of a technology for a device to be installed in every gas producing human to stem the emissions which would place the country at the forefront of the battle against climate change.
The devices can be removed on a weekly basis and form part of a green cities clean energy initiative taking us closer to carbon net zero.
We therefore ask the House to introduce a Bill to mandate such personal sequestration of methane by 2030 and to direct resources to the science to enable this to happen by 2030.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4689)
HomeBuilder

We are writing this petition to plead our case regarding the HomeBuilder Grant document cut-off date. As pre-approved applicants of the HBG, we were notified that all final grant documents must be submitted by April 30th, 2023 in order to obtain the grant.

Due to the ongoing pandemic, material shortages, and extreme weather conditions, many of us are expecting our houses to be ready after that date. While this may not impact some applicants, it poses a significant problem for those of us who have purchased an off-the-plan property. The required documents, such as the Certificate of Title or Certificate of Practical Completion, cannot be issued until the property is completed. This is a common aspect of buying an off-the-plan property, and one that we cannot control.
Despite meeting all required criteria for the grant and receiving formal letters of pre-approval, we are at risk of missing out on the life-changing grant due to this oversight.
We implore you to reconsider the cut-off date for those of us in this situation, as providing the final documentation before April 30th, 2023 is impossible for us.
We believe alternative conditions should be considered for off-the-plan applicants. We're seeking federal action on this matter as state departments cannot alter a federal grant scheme.

We therefore ask the House to consider an extension or alternative conditions made to the HBG documentation cut off date for all off-the-plan applicants, to consider their inability to obtain the necessary documentation prior to the completion of their homes.
from 450 citizens (Petition No. EN4691)
Taxation: Online Fundraising

Whilst most fundraisers use online fundraisers for good purposes ie one off emergencies, unplanned events etc, others are using these fund raisers multiple times to raise money for day to day living expenses. These groups / people are often involved with anti social activities. Funds raised this way, and used for day to day living expenses, should be subject to income tax rules.

We therefore ask the House to apply tests for the true purpose of money raised during online fund raisers. Those not raised for a "one off emergency" or "event" should be subject to the same rules for taxation on income.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4696)
Digital Platforms: Standards

It has become common practice for companies to use tactical measures to make it difficult for consumers to unsubscribe from their services. In many industries including newspaper services, media services, digital editing software and food subscription services, consumers are regularly required to surpass unecessary barriers to unsubscribe, such as having to access the company's website via a computer browser instead of via its app, needing to log in a second time to access a cancellation page or the cancellation being required by a method more onerous than that to the method available to change the type of subscription. These measures are clearly put in place to make it difficult to unsubscribe, and put a large collective burden on consumers.

We therefore ask the House to introduce new legislation or amend current legislation to require companies to enable consumers to unsubscribe to their services by the most simple and accessible means reasonably practicable.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN4697)
Sudden Cardiac Arrest
20,000 Australians each year suffer sudden cardiac arrest.
90% of casualties will not survive.

Having access to an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) can increase the recovery rate of cardiac arrest victims by 70%, without the life-saving intervention of an AED recovery rate is as low as 10%.
Every minute counts and without the intervention of an AED the likelihood of survival decreases.
AEDs in the community that are prominent, accessible, actionable and registered on an app will save lives.

We therefore ask the House to make it mandatory for businesses that have public access to be mandatorily required to have a prominent, accessible and actionable Automated External Defibrillator (AED) and register its location and access time on a mobile application (app) for quick location and retrieval to increase the survival rate of a casualty of sudden cardiac arrest
from 1,264 citizens (Petition No. EN4699)
Skilled Migration Program

The Migration Act 1958, and the Migration Regulations 1994 prohibit point-based skilled visa applicants who were single at their skilled visa application time from having non-citizen spouses or de facto partners at the decision time of their application. If such applicants have relationships during the visa processing and decision time, their application will be refused because they will lose the points they were awarded for being single at the invitation time to apply for the visa. This refusal cannot be appealed at a review tribunal because most skilled applicants do not have review rights, as they are usually located offshore. Even if onshore applicants are able to lodge a merits review of their refusal, they must remain single until a decision is made on their review application. Skilled migrants are an important part of Australia's migration intake because they bring highly valuable skills that the country needs. However, the long processing times for visas/review applications mean that they must remain single, even if they were invited to apply for a visa based on their skills, and cannot enter into a relationship with a non-citizen while their application is being processed. This appears unfair and has far-reaching unintended consequences.

We therefore ask the House to amend the law allowing point-based-skilled-visa-applicants who were single at visa lodgement to have a non-citizen spouse or de facto partner after they have applied for a point-based-skilled-visa, without negatively affecting their visa application due to their relationship with a non-citizen after submitting the visa application.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. EN4700)
Floods: New South Wales

We, the residents of Cabonne shire in Central West, New South Wales call on the Federal Government to make disaster relief grants made immediately available to residents/businesses owners that have sustained extensive damage to their properties and loss of possessions and resources as a result of recent extreme weather events in the area.

In many circumstances due to high premiums and the current economic situation many residents' homes, contents etc were uninsured effectively leaving many homeless and without livelihoods, unable to rebuild their communities

We therefore ask the House to bring forward and immediately enact proposed disaster relief grants (Such as the back-to-home grants) to assist the residents in the flood-stricken villages of Cabonne in rebuilding their homes, business, and communities.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN4701)

subdebateinfo.title: Health Care: Drug and Alcohol Rehabilitation

p.span: Health Care: Drug and Alcohol Rehabilitation

A lack of regulation over private alcohol and drug rehabilitation treatment centres has allowed some unscrupulous providers to prey on vulnerable participants and desperate families. Complaints ranged from concerns about providers misrepresenting the services they offer, staff members using drugs with clients, and police not being contacted when bail conditions are breached, to modern-day slavery and lack of therapy and correct medication.
We therefore ask the House to urgently regulate this sector.
from 73 citizens (Petition No. EN4704)
Family Law

If a party to a family law case makes accusations about a parents' mental health, the court orders a psychiatric/psychological assessment. The cost of such assessments are upwards of $2,000 and have a lengthy wait list.

The time and money involved in this process often results inability to adhere to court orders, delays in visitation or custodial access and alienation/criminalisation of a parent. Worse, it can lead to suicide of a parent that does, in fact, have a history of depression and ultimately loses hope that they will have access to their child.

While Legal-Aid currently can assist with the costs of the above assessments, the process is very long and the waitlist to see a professional even longer. These matters are time delicate and not being treated as urgent.
My sister committed suicide due to the inability to access an affordable and timely psychological assessment which she relied on for access to her child.
We therefore ask the House to publicly fund court-ordered psychiatric/psychological assessments and treat them as a matter of urgency.
from 197 citizens (Petition No. EN4705)
Skilled Migration Program

The purpose of visa sc 491/494 is to bring growth to the regional Australia and that's why they have to live and work there even though they get better job offer in metropolitan/city. However not being able to have access to benefits like First home buyer assistance, to have to pay 8% FIRB fee, no access to FEE help for further study have made these visa holders to somehow feel that they are not so important in contributing to the rural community/ and to the whole country, otherwise where is the "fair go". These visa holders have considered Australia their home, but why can't they buy a home same as other pr, do further study same as other pr, and have access to other benefits even when they do contribute equally, especially the regional areas.

We therefore ask the House to consider the fact that the visa sc 491/494 visa holders contribute to the economy, to the community equally same as other PR and no less and therefore be given same access to benefits to buying a house, and to further study on the same terms as permanent visa holders.
They had a hope when the "New Skilled Regional Visas (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2019" was presented to HoR but that could not proceed further because of Covid.
so now we would like to request the House to do something similar which would make the visa sc 491/494 feel included and made to feel an important part of this great country.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN4709)
International Relations: Australia and China

China has never kept its promises on important principle issues. She has not opened markets after joining WTO. It was a condition to do so. She has not kept its promises on HongKong, such as free election. Declaring Sino-British Joint Declaration on HK as a historical document. She promised not to militarise South China Sea but she has. How can Australia support China to join CPTPP knowing she has never kept promises? Therefore, it will not be in Australia's national interest to support China joining.
We therefore ask the House to debate the merit of supporting China joining CPTPP or legislate banning the government from supporting China to join CPTPP.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4711)
Medicinal Cannabis
For the future wellbeing of generations of Australians as there is overwhelming new evidence of the dangers of cannabis with the relaxation of laws in other countries that legalised cannabis.

We therefore ask the House to consider the roleback of medicinal marijuana use and ban unregulated access and use. There is overwhelming evidence of a scientific nature from other countries that show's in detail just how destructive this drug is. The only benefit from the legalisation in these countries was to gather scientific based evidence as proof that this drugs use is more harmful then beneficial to humans and their surrounding environment. It should be the number one priority of the Australian government to consult with this evidence so they do not lead future generations of Australians down the path of bad health care. Every Australian deserves good health care and complementary opportunity as it has proven itself over 100's of year's to be effective and they should have that chose.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4713)
Defence Recruitment

I passed everything to enter the ADF but was turned away when they learnt of my ADHD which I was upfront about from the very beginning. To say I was devastated is an understatement. I worked soo hard & passed soo many things I didn't think I could only to be turned away on medical grounds. It's disgusting that our own defense force discriminates against people with medical conditions they cannot help. This needs to change & change now. They even turn anaphylactic people away & it's not good enough. We know how to manage our disorders/ or medical conditions & should be just as accepted as anyone else is.
We therefore ask the House to change legislation when it comes to accepting people with these medical conditions to join the adf because as it currently stands it is unfair & very discriminatory.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN4715)
Remuneration and Entitlements

Given the recent pandemic issues with current management of individual health in the workplace in our country have become more apparent especially with the huge strain on our GP's and Hospitals. One reason for the strain is the way we deal with sick leave and medical certificates. Employees are capable of knowing when they are unwell enough to not attend their work and the current requirements where employers request medical certificates (ie absence the day before or the day after a normal day of work, absence on a public holiday, absence greater than 1 day) add a large and unnecessary burden on an already overloaded GP network and as many GP clinics now no longer bulk bill also a financial burden on employees.
We therefore ask the House to make the following changes:
1- the only requirement for an employee to present a medical certificate is an absence of 3 days or greater
2- employers should pay the entire cost of the medical appointment and fee for a medical certificate if they require it. It is always the employees choice of which doctor they see.
3- increase the amount of accumulated annual paid sick leave to from 10 days to 12 days

4- sick leave should be paid into a collective pool for an employee to carry with them throughout their working career so they do not have to start at 0 with a new employer. Any remaining balance at age of retirement is paid into the employees superannuation.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4716)
Aged Care
* Older people's complex medical needs require specialised care delivery by appropriately skilled and qualified staff such as Enrolled Nurses (ENS), Physios and Allied Health Professionals (AHPs)
* Without adequate levels of ENs and AHPS, older people have poorer health outcomes and quality of life, which leads to more load on other staff, the health system and taxpayers.

* The current Aged Care reforms provide no required minimum levels of ENS and AHPS, and they also do not count separately towards Star Ratings, to help older Australians and their representatives make more informed choices about their aged care.

*Penalties and threats for nursing homes not providing ENs and AHPS has not worked, with continuing job losses, cuts to hours, as well as remaining staff having excessive workloads, and lack of job security.
* This leaves our mums and dads with a poorer quality of life without sufficient levels of clinical care to keep moving, manage pain, falls, being admitted to hospital and dying early.
We therefore ask the House to

* Require minimum minutes of clinical care delivery for a nursing home resident to receive by ENs and AHPs set at levels as per evidence presented at the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety.
* Publicly report staffing minutes of ENs and AHPs compared against state and national averages.
* Have these levels of ENs and AHPs count separately towards staff care minutes in Star Ratings
from 627 citizens (Petition No. EN4717)
Permanent Residence Visas

We (batch of Feb—2019) came to Australia to pursue our educational endeavours and the pandemic hit in Nov/Dec 2019. During the pandemic, we stayed-put in Australia without family—completed our uni courses (paying full college fees for online classes). And, we now somehow managed to land into decent respectable professional jobs.

After going through so many challenges while studying, we are still required to go through another list of hoops for the Australian permanent residency (i.e. work on points to satisfy the requirements etc) just to make an honest living in Australia.

We therefore ask the House to reduce the requirements for the permanent residency for those (batch of Feb—2019, like myself) who lived through very tough times without family in Australia throughout COVID, completed educational degrees, landed into professional respectable jobs and are making an honest living in Australia.
I/we ask this because Australia is all about diversity, culture and empathy. And supporting this helps to make this country standout compared to the others in a global forum.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN4718)
Bali Nine

Enough is enough. A life sentence in an Indonesian jail where foreigners are treated as less than human and are sentenced worse than murderers is a living nightmare. The punishment far out weighs the crime. These men need to be brought home.
We therefore ask the House to push to bring the remaining bali nine home.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN4721)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Current COVID outbreak in China. It is necessary to ensure people coming from China is not carrying the virus.
We therefore ask the House to implement rules for people from China has a negative COVID result before entering the country
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4722)
Health Care
Medicine

We therefore ask the House to examine medical profession the medical industry is covered under federal law so this is federal matter. Schedule 8 meds are being taken of people in every state . schedule 8 meds are pain meds above Panadol if doctors prescribe schedule 8 meds they get interrogated by health industry. This is in every state. Chronic pain suffers can't get medical help because they are scared to issue even hospitals refuse to issue schedule 8 meds to chronic pain suffers this is every state .this needs to change
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4725)
COVID-19: Biosecurity

Australian Citizens do not wish our health and that of our families to being exposed to new variants especially as many of us have been extremely ill with Covid before and have not fully recovered. If this was happening in any other country we would be requesting similar bans.
We therefore ask the House to Ban Travel From China to Australia during this time of outbreak
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4726)
COVID-19: Biosecurity

Due to recent surge Covid cases and the high causality in China. We should protect our people from exposing to the risk. In past 2 years, our health system and personnel has been under severe pressure. If we did nothing in our border and allow all the potential Covid-carrier into our country. It will be a disaster to all of us.
We therefore ask the House to pass law to request all Passengers arriving Australia from China must have to take PCR test and only negative test result passenger can board the plane to Australia.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4728)
Medicare
The Medicare rebate has not kept pace with funding GP's to the appropriate level of remuneration, and as such, bulk billing has disappeared.
GP's have moved into other areas and medical students are being discouraged from entering general practice.
Many can no longer afford to visit their GP as often as necessary, particularly those with complex and multiple health issues.

Petitioner requests that the Federal Minister for Health and their State Government counterparts enter into urgent discussions with all sides of politics, with a view the increasing the Medicare rebate as a matter of urgency, to ensure GP's are retained, and medical students are encouraged to pursue such a career.
Bulk billing again must be encouraged.

We therefore ask the House to urgently enter into discussions to rectify the very large and unfair gap paid to medical practitioners involved in general practice, to encourage appropriate remuneration with respect to skills and experience, in order to retain current GP's, and attract medical students to this area of medicine.
We then expect that bulk billing may again be introduced to allow all citizens to be Abe able to access quality medical care regardless of their economic situation.
from 119 citizens (Petition No. EN4729)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
I harbour a deep concern regarding Anthony Albanese's stance upon the lack of testing of Chinese citizens flying to Australia from China.

The CCP are deliberately opening up their borders and allowing their citizens to travel as they are unable to control the spread of COVID in their society and want to inflict the same circumstances upon the rest of the world to create a "new playing field". They did this exact same thing in 2020. They have been caught sending plane loads of infected people into Italy. This occurred in Milan where on the 29th December 2022 it was found that over 50% of passengers had COVID. This is a deliberate act by the CCP and allowing their citizens to travel at this time, in these circumstances only serves to promote their own interests. An investigation should be undertaken regarding their motivations for doing this.

I am aware that Australia as a whole has a high percentage of citizens that have been vaccinated or have been infected. This is no guarantee of protection from variants which have been allowed to mutate in a different environment for several years.
I implore anyone with our national interests at heart to carefully consider this petition

We therefore ask the House to impose the strictest possible border controls on any passengers from China to protect our citizens and society as a whole. The risk of not doing this is that we will be taken back to March 2020.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4731)
COVID-19: Biosecurity

From 5 January 2023, travellers to China will be required to undertake a COVID-19 test within the 48hrs prior to travel and show evidence of a negative test result when returning to Australia. This restriction has ostensibly been introduced to detect the emergence of new variants.
The virus will mutate and new strains will arise. There is no reason to believe that they will be more dangerous than existing strains.

The situation in China is unremarkable. The virus has been circulating in China since at least late 2019. China may currently be experiencing a wave, but that wave will crest and fall, as have all previous waves in all other countries. What is happening in China is no justification for introducing any new Covid restrictions.

Past experience shows that restrictions tend to snowball. Australians do not want additional restrictions requiring travellers to wear masks, quarantine, and so on. It would be totally unacceptable to see restrictions expanded to the general population.
We therefore ask the House to immediately remove all restrictions on travellers from China and not impose any additional Covid restrictions on Australians.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4732)
Child Abuse

Recently the world of elites has made a swing in favour of the legalisation of pedophilia and to eradicate the demonisation against people who choose this "sexual orientation". I am begging for this to not be accepted and to realise the impact it will have on children's long term mental health if we allow this to be decriminalised. We are meant to protect our children and keep them from danger, but it seems the World Economic Forum thinks otherwise.

We therefore ask the House to please set in stone the permanent criminalisation of any sexual acts with minors, keep the age of consent at 18, sentence harshly to those who engage in any act that sexualises children under the age of 18 including online and in person.
Please keep our children safe and have clear cut laws in place so as we move forward those lines never get blurred!
from 127 citizens (Petition No. EN4736)
National Library of Australia: Trove
To save the Trove Website so researchers like myself that cannot get to main libraries can use.
We therefore ask the House to help save the website Trove that is run by the National Library of Australia
from 390 citizens (Petition No. EN4737)
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
While those without concession cards now pay $12.50 less per medication (for those at the maximum PBS price), those with concession cards pay 50c MORE for their medications.
With the soaring cost of living, it is unconscionable to increase the cost of a necessity *only* for the poorest in our community. They need your protection the most and you are letting them down.
We therefore ask the House to reverse the increase in PBS prices to those with concession cards.
from 63 citizens (Petition No. EN4744)
National Library of Australia: Trove

Our heritage and culture is our identity as a nation and denying access to the hundreds of thousands of Australians who access TROVE on a regular basis is not acceptable. TROVE attracts over 20 million hits a year and is a world leader in concept and material. It is the envy of archives in other countries.
The National Library has been operating on life support level funding for some time and rather than reducing funding it should be, at a minimum, maintained, if not increased.
Our culture, history and access to it, should be neutral and respected equally no matter which party holds government. Ongoing funding should be a given no matter who holds the purse strings.

For historians, researchers, students, authors and creatives this is an emergency. Government must to find the funds. Our heritage and archives regularly take a back seat and this cannot be allowed to happen in regards to TROVE.

Access to this historical information cannot be purely limited to those who can afford to personally visit the archives. TROVE gives access to each and every Australian no matter where they live. If TROVE ceases it removes the ability to electronically search the data bases of the national memory and that would seriously limit any future research in this field.
We therefore ask the House to fully fund TROVE and the National Library that administers the site.
from 6,384 citizens (Petition No. EN4745)
Human Rights: China

People from the Turkic ethnic groups in Northwest China including Uyghurs, Kazakhs, Uzbek and Tatars are currently the target of the largest organized detention of an ethno-religious community the world has seen since World War II. Since 2017, more than one million people have been rounded up and put into 1,200 internment camps across East Turkistan (Xinjiang). Hundreds of thousands are enslaved for the benefit of major international brands in the factories around those camps. Forced labour conditions include: o restrictions on the movement of labourers, o debt bondage, o constant digital surveillance, o forced isolation, o forced sterilization, o abusive working conditions, and o the withholding of wages. People detained are forcibly pushed to do low-skilled, labour-intensive work across the textile, garment, and automotive sectors. The Australian Government has taken steps to address China's human rights violations In East Turkistan (Xinjiang) in recent years. However, its action is much behind than other democratic countries. Australia must take a strong stand against the well documented abuse of millions of Uyghur people in Xinjiang. It would be a human rights disgrace if Australia, under our free trade agreement with China, turned a blind eye to profiteering from what amounts to slave labour.

We therefore ask the House to call on the Australian Government to fulfil its pre-election promises to address issues of Uyghur forced labour by passing the Customs Amendment (Banning Goods Produced By Uyghur Forced Labour) Bill 2021.
from 548 citizens (Petition No. EN4746)
National Library of Australia: Trove

Trove is an online archive that provides access to a huge range of archives free to all Australians. It is the memory house for the nation and imperative for researchers, genealogists, family historians and students. It receives 20 million hits a year and is a vital part of Australian heritage.
Currently, funding for Trove expires in July 2023.
We therefore ask the House to fully fund Trove so that the nation's memories can be accessed by all Australians and provides them with the opportunity to understand and know our own history.
from 22,240 citizens (Petition No. EN4747)
Housing
There is no disputing Australia is in the grip of a housing crisis, yet remains without a National Housing Strategy or even National Inquiry. This can no longer wait. It is urgent.

Reports, research and statistics from welfare groups, charities, government departments, on housing insecurity and homelessness -even the University of NSW 'City Futures Research Centre' as well as the lived experiences of Australians appear to be falling on deaf ears. Meanwhile the situation escalates.
We therefore ask the House to establish a Royal Commission into the national housing crisis: including: causes, consequences & the need to establish National Housing Strategy.

Amongst it's terms of reference, a Royal Commission must also ascertain whether Australia is failing it's obligation that "Everyone has the right to an adequate standard of living which includes housing..." as stated in Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

The Royal Commission must also allow provision for Australian's to provide statements of personal lived experience within the current housing crisis; whether that be public housing, private rental, crisis accommodation, homelessness, would be or entering housing market. Including the impact their circumstances have had on stability and access to: employment, education/training, childcare, healthcare, public transport etc.
In designing the terms of reference should include in its structure key elements outlined within research and report by, Duncan Maclennan, Jinqiao Long (University of Glasgow)
Hal Pawson, Bill Randolph, Fatemeh Aminpour (City Futures Research Centre, UNSW)
Chris Leishman (University of South Australia) and titled 'Housing: Taming The Elephant in the Economy'
from 14,496 citizens (Petition No. EN4753)
Refugee and Humanitarian Program

There are approximately 15000 refugees living in our community on Temporary Protection Visas and Safe Haven Enterprise Visa with many more thousands of asylum seekers applications to be processed. Many of these refugees come from Afghanistan and it is crucial they are able to bring their families to safety. Their current visa conditions prevent them from doing this. These visa also disadvantage refugees in other ways such as placing limits on education, employment and more.

We therefore ask the House to immediately grant permanent protection visa to all refugees currently on Temporary Protection Visas and Safe Haven Enterprise Visa and to expedite the processing of asylum seeker applications and also grant them permanent protection.
from 73 citizens (Petition No. PN0554)
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 10 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Cybersafety
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to the email of 22 November 2021 from the previous Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd MP, to the then Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, the Hon Paul Fletcher MP, concerning Petition EN3472. The Petition calls for the Government to recognise scams as an act of terrorism, and to enact new legislation requiring communications information technology and online media providers to prevent scams and hold them accountable for enabling them.
I understand that the Committee did not receive a response from the previous Government.

The Australian Government acknowledges the impact of online scams. Last year alone, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) estimated scams cost Australians close to $2 billion. The ACCC estimates that scam losses may have exceeded $4 billion in 2022.

This Government has committed to a range of new measures to combat scams and online fraud. This includes establishing a National Anti-Scam Centre, new industry codes, and more funding for identification recovery services.

This is a new approach that combines the resources of the private sector, Commonwealth, states, and territories while recognising private sector businesses are the 'front line' in anti-scam efforts. The 2022-23 Budget in October provided $12.6 million for these commitments and the Government will consider further measures to combat scams in future.

On 11 November 2022, the Treasurer, the Hon Jim Chalmers MP, and the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, the Hon Dr Andrew Leigh MP, released the ACCC's 5th interim report for the Digital Platforms Services Inquiry. The report recommends, in part, that the Government introduce digital platform-specific consumer measures to prevent and remove scams, harmful apps and fake reviews, including dispute resolution processes.

Treasury has begun public consultation on the recommendations contained in the report through a consultation paper released on 20 December 2022. The deadline for submissions in response to this consultation paper is 15 February 2023 and I encourage members of the public to engage in this consultation process to ensure that their views on the ACCC's recommendations are heard. More information on the consultation process is at www.treasury.gov.au/consultation/c2022-341745.
I thank the Committee for bringing these concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
International Development Assistance
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for the correspondence from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) regarding petition EN3549 on new foreign relations rules.

This petition was received by the former Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd MP, on 14 February 2022. DFAT has examined its records and has advised that no response to this petition was approved by the former minister on behalf of the former government. Accordingly, I am pleased to provide the following response on behalf of the current government.

Australia's engagement with foreign governments is guided by our desire to create a world that is stable, peaceful, prosperous and respectful of sovereignty. We have a strong history of protecting human rights and promoting international peace.
Australia recognises states, not governments. The Australian Government does not extend or withhold formal recognition to new governments.

Australia uses every diplomatic tool at its disposal to advance our foreign policy priorities, consistent with our values and interests. This includes statements expressing concern, the withdrawal foreign aid and the imposition sanctions.
Thank you for bringing the views expressed in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Wong
Northern Territory
Dear Chair

On 14 February 2022 the then Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd, wrote to the then Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Territories, the Hon Nola Marino MP, regarding petition EN3572. I understand an Australian Government response to the petition is outstanding and the petition has been referred to me as the Minister now responsible for Territories.

The petition requests the House of Representatives take certain actions to 'resume federal control' of the Northern Territory (NT) due to the petitioner's loss of confidence in the NT Government. Section 122 of the Australian Constitution empowers the Parliament of Australia to make laws in relation to Territories. The Parliament has conferred a large measure of self-government on the people of the NT through the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978.

The Australian Government does not propose amending NT self-government arrangements. This Government continues to work closely with the NT Government on a range of matters, including ensuring appropriate oversight of Government investment in the NT. Concerns with the NT Government's performance should be raised through the NT Legislative Assembly.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Regional Development, Local Government and Territories, Ms McBain
Veterans
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding Parliamentary Petition EN4196 which states: 'The Administrate Appeals Tribunal (AAT) has delegated legislation by way of the "person giving expert or opinion evidence guideline" (guide). The guide applies to parties before the AAT, and ensures natural justice prevails…An anomaly exists in that information adduced by persons giving expert or opinion evidence in matters before the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission, the Repatriation Commission (Commissions) and the Veterans Review Board (Board) to do so, in a manner which does not conform to that of the AAT guide…This double standard disadvantages Veteran claimants and applicants, and result in them having to unnecessarily appeal a matter to the AAT to receive natural justice…It is widely acknowledged that appealing a matter to the AAT is a complex and stressful process, not the least because the Commissions can engage legal representation. It is also a needless burden to the Commonwealth purse and resources of the Commission, Board and AAT…This anomaly can be overcome if the VEA were amended in such a way which would require persons giving expert or opinion evidence in a matter before the Commissions and Board, to do so from the onset in a manner which confo1med to the AAT guide.'

Petition EN4196 requests that the House "initiate such processes that will cause such an amendment to the Veterans Acts as to result in persons giving expert or opinion evidence in matters before the Commissions and Board, to do so in a manner which aligns with the AAT guide."

The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA), the Military, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA) and the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation (Defence-related Claims) Act 1988 (DRCA) each contain various provisions which govern the procedural powers of the Repatriation Commission, the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission (together, the Commissions) and the Veterans' Review Board (Board) in relation to the gathering and taking of evidence for the purposes of investigating, determining and reviewing claims. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 contains similar procedural powers in relation to the provision of information or documents and the giving of evidence (see sections 33, 40 and 40A). As the AAT's Guideline for 'Persons Giving Expert and Opinion Evidence' (AAT Guideline) is not a legislative instrument, and the relevant procedural powers are contained in the respective Acts, no legislative amendment to the VEA (or MRCA or DRCA) would be necessary if the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) were to adopt the AAT Guideline (or other similar guidelines).
It is also relevant to note the recent announcement of the Australian Government that the AAT will be abolished and replaced with a new federal administrative review body.

In any event, the AAT Guideline is designed to inform parties and persons giving evidence about the AAT's expectations in relation to oral evidence and any written report prepared for the purpose of proceedings in the AAT. The AAT is the final tier merits review body reviewing veterans' entitlements decisions. By contrast, the Commissions operate at a primary or internal review level and the Board as the first tier merits review body.

At the initial stages of claims assessment, it is beneficial to veterans that no additional burden is applied on them to require any evidence provided is to comply with prescribed guidelines. Ordinarily and preferably, claims will be decided based on information from the veteran's own treating General Practitioner and/or treating specialist. DVA does not wish to create any additional barriers for veterans submitting their own evidence. Further, any requirement to comply with the AAT Guideline may adversely impact on claims processing and result in delays.

Where an independent medical examination is required, DVA has contractual arrangements with providers. These arrangements set out the standards that the provider must comply with in addition to their professional medical obligations.
